thread.title: NHS plan to hire 2,000 overseas doctors a short term fix says North East expert

author: Katie Dickinson
title: NHS plan to hire 2,000 overseas doctors a short term fix says North East expert
text:
News NHS plan to hire 2,000 overseas doctors a short term fix says North East expert NHS England announced this week that it will launch a global search for 2,000 more doctors in a bid to solve Britain’s GP crisis Share   Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
The NHS plan to hire 2,000 overseas doctors is vital to help the North East cope with its “serious GP crisis”, a health official has said. 
Dr George Rae said the region urgently needs a “sticking plaster” as a struggle to recruit GPs has left many practices struggling to cope with demand from patients - and even to stay open. 
NHS England announced this week it is to launch a global search for 2,000 more doctors in a bid to solve Britain’s GP crisis. 
The service’s chief Simon Stevens said four times the 500 extra doctors that had been planned were needed from countries such as New Zealand, Australia and the rest of the EU . 
Whitley Bay GP Dr Rae welcomed the news but said it was not a long-term solution. Dr George Rae from Whitley Bay (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
He added that Brexit means the NHS could struggle to recruit doctors from EU countries. 
Dr Rae, who is the British Medical Association’s (BMA) North East chair, said: “We have a very serious recruitment and retention crisis in the North East. 
“There are some practices in the region which are having to close because of the inability to recruit GPs. 
“I also know some practices who have sought permission to close their lists over the past few months, meaning they are not taking on any new patients, because they’re finding it totally impossible to give a proper service to patients. 
“We need a sticking plaster to help but this is now happening against the backdrop of Brexit and it won’t be as easy to get people to come over here as it would have been two or three years ago.” 
Dr Rae added: “In the long-term, something needs to be done to make general practice more attractive to new doctors because there is a serious problem in the NHS at the moment.” Dr George Rae
